original_data.question: A 55-year-old man presents to a rheumatologist with bilateral wrist and knee pain that has been present for the last 10 years. The patient was a professional athlete who retired at age 50. He also notes morning stiffness in his joints that lasts approx. 50 minutes. He denies joint swelling, color changes in his digits, dryness of mucous membranes, and constitutional symptoms such as fever and chills. On physical exam, the physician notes several non-tender nodules on the left 1st, 3rd, and 4th distal interphalangeal joints. There is also tenderness with palpation at the base of both thumbs. The patient’s knees are enlarged, bilaterally, and he has pain and crepitus on passive range of motion. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

model_response:
The patient’s clinical presentation is most consistent with osteoarthritis. He is an older man with a history of joint pain and swelling, with morning stiffness. The distribution of joint involvement is typical for osteoarthritis, with the DIP and PIP joints of the hands and the knees being the most commonly affected joints. The non-tender Heberden’s and Bouchard’s nodes are classic for osteoarthritis. The first CMC joint is also commonly involved in osteoarthritis. The spine is not involved in osteoarthritis.

###Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Physicians who specialize in treating RHEUMATIC DISEASES.
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the knee. [UToronto:chum]
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
**Description:**Primarily in the British Imperial culture people tend to have an abbreviation of their professional organization as part of their credential titles.
How long something has existed; elapsed time since birth.
Also known as articulations, these are points of connection between the ends of certain separate bones, or where the borders of other bones are juxtaposed.
A precursor cell which gives rise to a fully differentiated cell of hematopoietic lineage.
A unit measure of time equal to 60 seconds.
The presence of swelling in a joint.
The visually perceived property of objects created by absorption or reflection of specific wavelengths of light.
The act of alteration or modification; changed or altered in form or character.
A finger or toe in human beings or corresponding part in other vertebrates.
The lack of natural or normal moisture.

An EPITHELIUM with MUCUS-secreting cells, such as GOBLET CELLS. It forms the lining of many body cavities, such as the DIGESTIVE TRACT, the RESPIRATORY TRACT, and the reproductive tract. Mucosa, rich in blood and lymph vessels, comprises an inner epithelium, a middle layer (lamina propria) of loose CONNECTIVE TISSUE, and an outer layer (muscularis mucosae) of SMOOTH MUSCLE CELLS that separates the mucosa from submucosa.
A group of symptoms that affect an individual's general well being. Representative examples include fever, chills, fatigue, weakness, and weight loss.
An abnormal elevation of body temperature, usually as a result of a pathologic process.
The sudden sensation of being cold. It may be accompanied by SHIVERING.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the west when facing north.
Situated farthest from a point of attachment or origin, as of a limb or bone; or directed away from the midline of the body.
Hinge joints between the phalanges of the hand or foot.
A dull achy pain.
Application of fingers with light pressure to the surface of the body to determine consistence of parts beneath in physical diagnosis; includes palpation for determining the outlines of organs.

A substance that dissociates to give hydroxide ions in aqueous solutions; a substance capable of donating a pair of electrons (to an acid) for the formation of a coordinate covalent bond; a substance whose molecule or ion can combine with a proton (hydrogen ion); a substance that combines with acids to form salts.
The first digit on the radial side of the hand which in humans lies opposite the other four.
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by NERVE ENDINGS of NOCICEPTIVE NEURONS.
Air trapped in the subcutaneous space. It can be palpated or heard as a crackling or grating sensation under the skin.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.
